docs.title: Lacewing Text Protocol
docs.text: LWTP is a simple text information serving protocol.

docs.title: Getting started
docs.text:
First, you need to create a Github repository named 'lwtp'. I think I don't need to explain how to do this.

Second, create a file named 'welcome' without any extensions. The content of it will be displayed when someone connects to server.

Welcome to my LWTP site! Hello world! Lorem ipsum etc idontwannawriteitblahblahblah

It can also be dynamic. I did some examples in Clickteam Fusion 2.5 which contains a web server that can be controlled with events.

We have a global value 'peerCount' that literally is a counter of people who are online right now. When the client tries to fetch the welcome text we add 1 to 'peerCount' value and respond it for user. When it disconnects using the according command, it also sends a GET request to {server}/lwtp/disconnect, so we substract 1 from 'peerCount'

Code (CTF2.5):

On GET request 'lwtp/welcome':
    Add 1 to [peerCount]

    Add string to response:
    "Welcome! There are " + Str$(peerCount) + " users online!"


On GET request 'lwtp/disconnect'
    Sub 1 from [peerCount]

What does it looks like for user:

Time to start your server!

  • tps <port> - Starts a dynamic server on selected port (leave empty for 80 which is default)

Theoretically you can even use PHP, but I don't know how to code in it. But you can also use any HTTP server, but then your site will remain static which is freaking BORING!
